> Another question: I would love to be able to run one instance of each popular ethereum client, like geth, open ethereum, besu, etc. However, as each client stores the state in its own different way, each one needs to have a seperate copy of the ethereum state. I guess there's no way to avoid this but wondering if once a chain is downloaded by one client if it can be transformed to the format expected by the other clients? And if that might be a project worth pursuing?
<@!387536747476549632> I'm a bit late on this, but I have a branch of py-evm which can read from Geth's database format, so you can use Trinity against a Geth database. I also have a script which goes a step further and imports a geth database, turning it into a database which Trinity can run against. One problem with the idea is that importing a Geth database into TurboGeth is going to take a very long time, and It would probably take a lot of effort to make a version of TurboGeth which can operate against a Geth database, it almost ruins the point of using TurboGeth ðŸ™‚
